org.orgName: The United States Circuit Court for the District of Washington

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Petition of James P. Lavin, Immigrant Inspector and Sister M. Angelique, Sister Superior of the House of thex Good Shepard, for a Writ of Certiorari} No. 1078

Comes now James P. Lavin and Sister M. Angelique, petitioners above named, by Edward E. Cushman, Assistant United States Attorney, and for an answer and return to the writ and petition for habeas corpus of Yvonne Le Fevre, Marie Le Fevre and Georgette Normand,shows the Court:
I.
That they admit the allegations contained in paragraphs one and two and deny the allegations of paragraphs three, save as herinafter explained and qualified
II.

They deny the allegations of paragraph four. For a further return and answer to said petition and writ your petitioners shows: That prior to the filing of the application for a writ of habeas corpus herein you petitioner, James P. Lavin, was and still in a revenue officer of the Tresury Department, to-wit, Immigrant Inspector for the collection district of Puget Sound; that each said applicants for writ of habeas corpus, to-wit, Yvonne Le Fevre, Marie Le Fevre and Georgette Normand, is a native citizen of the Republic of France: that your petitioner, James P.Lavin, heretofore, in the discharge of his duties as such officer, on the 9th day of February, 1903, temporarily removed said applicats from the steamship Rosalie upon its arrival in Seattle from the foreign port of Victoria, British Columbia, from which port it has brought said applicats: that said removal was for the purpose of determining and investigating whether they were immigrants
and properly entitled to enter the United States, and not for the purpose of landing them in the United States in any sense; that thereafter a board of special inquiry was convened of the Treasury officials and revenue officers, according to law and the regulations of the Treasury Department, to determine the eligibility of the above named applicats to land and enter the United States: that upon such investigation it was found and determined that said immigrants had within one year prior thereto been imported into the United States at the port of New York from France for the purpose of prostitution: that it was further found and determined that each one of them was a pauper and liable to become a public charge: that it was further found that immediatly prior to their having been taken from said vessel from such purpose by your petiioner, James P. Lavin, they had left the United States and gone to Victoria, British Columbia, from which place they were returning to the United States when so taken and removed; that upon this state of facts it was found and determined that they were not lawfully entitled to be in or enter the United States and that they should be deported and returned to the county to which they belonged and from whence they came: that the question of whether they be deported to British Columbia of France was and still is held under advisement and is in process of determination by the proper officials of the Treasury Department; that upon the conclusion of the facts and findings in this case tox the Collector of Customs at Port Townsend, and that said report and findings were forwarded by Collector of Customs upon the 13th day of February, 1903, to the Secretary of the Tresury, by whom it will be determined to what country the applicants should be deported; that pending said final determination by the Secretary of the Tresury your petioners, James P. Lavin and Sister M. Angelique, by his direction and authority as such Immigrant Inspector, are for the purpose that these applicants may be held to answer the disposition that is made of thier case by the Secretary
-2-
of the Treasury, held and restrained of their liberty, and not otherwise; that they are so held and retrained at the express direction and by the express warrant of the Secretary of the Treasury.
Wherefore, your petitioners pray that the writ of habeas corpus be denied, and that the applicants be remanded to their custody.
Edward E Cushman Assistant United States Attorney
United States of America District of Washington} ss
James P Lavin by facts does sworn on oath say he is one of the petitioner above named and he has read the foregoing and knows its contents thereof and that the same is true
James P. Lavin
Subscribed and sworn to before me the 15th of Feb 1903
R M Hopkins Clerk of the U.S. District Court, District of Washington
Due and full service of within acknowledge this day of, 189 Attorney for
TX
FORM NO.499 NO.1078
IN THE Circiut COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON Northern Division.

THE UNITED STATES VS.
In re petition Lavin et al for Certiorari etc.
Anwer of US.
FILED IN THE U.S.Circuit Court, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON FEB 16 1903 A. REVES AYRES Clerkf RM Hspkins Dep Jesse A. Frye
WILSON R. GAY, UNITED STATES ATTORNEY, SEATTLE, WASHINGTON.
